10018.description: Teen Arts Program Portfolio Mentorship Program Free Arts NYC empowers underserved youth through art and mentoring programs to develop their creativity, confidence, and skills to succeed. What is the Teen Art Portfolio Mentorship Program? As a volunteer in the Portfolio Mentorship Program, you’ll have the opportunity to mold a young artist while developing your own skills as an artist and educator. During weekly sessions, you’ll guide your mentee through the technical and artistic process of creating a visual portfolio, practice interview and audition skills, while serving as a positive role model. By the end of the program, you will both have shared and strengthened your arts backgrounds and your mentee will have applied to an arts high school or college! Time Commitment ● Pairs will meet weekly for 2-3 hours from April- December ● Mentors can expect to spend an additional hour each week commuting, creating lesson plans, and completing Free Arts NYC online evaluations or monthly phone calls ● Attendance to H.S. Open Houses, Interviews & Auditions, where possible As a Portfolio Mentor You Can Expect Free Arts to Provide ● Six hours of professional development trainings in Youth Development ● Portfolio Mentorship manual (includes resources on pair bonding, goal setting, portfolio development, and interviewing / auditioning) ● Dedicated Teen Arts Program staff support, including weekly online & individual monthly check-ins ● Monthly lesson plan clinics with fellow volunteers and Free Arts NYC staff ● Networking with other arts education professionals Portfolio Mentor Responsibilities ● Utilizing Portfolio Mentorship manual and TAP Manager support, create a plan for all sessions that ensures teen’s goals are met ● Support mentee in improving their artistic skills, culminating with the creation and mounting of 20 original portfolio pieces ● Help mentee to develop interview / audition skills, as necessary Portfolio Mentor Applicant Requirements ● BFA, MFA, or working knowledge of foundational art skills ● Portfolio development experience ● Minimum 1 year NYC residency TAP Portfolio Mentor Application Process 1. Complete Free Arts NYC’s Online Application 2. Supplemental Application, including a resume & portfolio of 3-5 pieces 3. Interview with Free Arts Staff & References ( 2 professional, 1 personal) 4. Fingerprinting with GoPass 5. Attend two required trainings and a meeting with mentee (Youth Development Training on February 24th or March 7th, Portfolio Mentorship Training on March 10th or March 14th - Meet your teen on Saturday, April 14th!) APPLICATION DEADLINE: March 1st Interested mentors will be required to submit an application and attend a New Volunteer Orientation. Complete a supplemental application on http://www.freeartsnyc.org/volunteer. Any Questions? Please Contact: brandy@freeartsnyc.org
10018.title: Be an Arts Mentor with our Portfolio Mentorship Program!

10018.description: Our volunteers create a memorable experience for our donors by executing what we call the \"special sauce\" of our Thank‑You Package Process. Donors who give more than $50 to a project have the chance to receive handwritten student thank-you notes-the \"special sauce\" of our Thank-You Packages. We receive hundreds of packages each day (sometimes thousands!) from classrooms across the country full of thank-yous. That's where you come in. Volunteers review the thank-yous to protect student privacy, check them into our computer system, repackage them, and mail them off to eager donors - all within 24 hours. After the first few months of their work, our volunteers report a newfound appreciation of glitter-art and an uncanny ability to speed-decipher third-grade handwriting.
10018.title: Volunteer at DonorsChoose.org!

10018.description: The WGIRLS NYC is a philanthropic organization of women dedicated to empowering women and children in under-served communities. We volunteer, raise funds, and provide support for women and children in need while developing our leadership skills and making lifelong friends. If you are a professional woman between the ages of 21-45 and would like to learn more about membership, please join us for an informational meeting on 1/24 in midtown at 8pm. Address provided with RSVP. About Us: Our Mission - WGIRLS is a philanthropic organization of women dedicated to empowering women and children in under-served communities by volunteering and providing support, while training our members to develop them into effective volunteers. The WGIRLS INC is an international not for profit women’s membership organization with chapters throughout the United States and United Kingdom. WGIRLS chapters are united in the mission to provide underprivileged women and children with the support and resources necessary to achieve health, happiness, and the ability to lead productive and successful adult lives. Additionally, in times of international crisis, the WGIRLS extend support outside the local community to address the global need. Chapters host several fundraising events throughout the year with proceeds supporting customized WGIRLS programming within the local community and/or are donated to local, pre-selected,501 C3 organizations that share our vision to support underprivileged women and children. Programming includes outreach to disadvantaged children during the holidays, meals for guests of the American Cancer Society’s Hope Lodge, Project (G.L.A.M) Granting Lasting Amazing Memories which outfits thousands of economically disadvantaged girls for their high school prom. \"WE\" - is what WGIRLS is all about. \"WE\" are a group of professional women across the country. The WGIRLS thrives on the diversity of our membership. \"WE\" embrace every members unique talents and gifts and encourage one another to use them in an effort to further our mission.
10018.title: Join the WGIRLS INC (NYC Chapter)

10018.description: Sing for Hope transforms and uplifts individuals and communities by mobilizing artists in volunteer service, bringing the power of the arts to those who need it most. Our programs include collaborative concerts for hospital patients, after-school arts classes for NYC youth, and our flagship initiative, The Sing for Hope Pianos. SFH Project Leaders make it possible for us to bring to life our mission of \"art for all.\" By leading Sing for Hope's programming at hospitals, veterans centers, community organizations and more, Project Leaders provide a critical link between our Artist Partners and on-site staff at partner organizations, and ensure high-quality experiences for all involved. Project Leaders are vital to Sing for Hope's ability to bring the arts to as many New Yorkers as possible. As a Project Leader we ask you to: Collaborate with Sing for Hope staff to plan program content for upcoming sessions Coordinate Sing for Hope programs at our partner sites, welcome and guide Volunteer Artists, and set a warm and positive tone throughout each program Serve as point of contact for VAs and site staff during programs, problem-solving as necessary Communicate with Sing for Hope as needed during and following programs Report back by sharing photos, quotes, and metrics with Sing for Hope staff via online surveys/email As a Project Leader, you will: Commit to a minimum of 2 hours of volunteer service a month for 6 months Complete the SFH Project Leader Training module (half day workshop) in August or September Attend your pre-determined scheduled programs (SFH programs take place during the daytime, evenings, or on weekends) As a Project Leader, you'll benefit by: Gaining invaluable, on-the-ground leadership experience Building your resume Meeting an amazing array of terrific Volunteer Artists Receiving ongoing feedback, support, and professional development Helping uplift individuals and communities Qualifications Must be 18 or older Strong public speaking, facilitation, and communication skills Personable, flexible, proactive, and comfortable solving problems as needed Basic technology skills (ie photography on camera or smartphone, email, online survey) Artistic ability is a plus, but not required Background check as required by partner organizations \"Being a Sing for Hope Project Leader gives the chance to offer kindness and love to those in circumstances that are often beyond our realm of understanding. It's a great responsibility, but an even greater privilege. I discovered almost immediately that I was able to dig much deeper into myself than I thought was possible. I discovered a kind of selfless love inside myself, a kindness that I didn't know I had. Being a Project Leader is a gift.\" - Abby Powell, Sing for Hope Project Leader
10018.title: BE PART OF THE ART! Become a Sing for Hope Project Leader

Mentoring Programs. The L.O.V.E. Mentoring Program aims to enhance academic performance and high school graduation rates among young Latinas by providing them with the support of positive role models. Mentoring sessions concentrate on developing study skills, enabling college access, and facilitating self-empowerment activities. This year we will be offering the exciting opportunity to mentor a student from public high schools throughout New York City. Mentors will meet with mentees on schools' campuses on a weekly basis for an hour and a half. 10018.description: BCA Global is searching for an intern to assist us for the Winter/Spring of 2016. Here is a bit of information about the BCA. In today's changing and challenging environment education will be a minimum requirement to attain career success and advancement in any industry. The same holds true for the culinary and hospitality industry, the largest industry in America today. As the foodservice industry continues to develop, it will depend upon the services of a highly trained workforce. BCA plays an important role in preparing students and professionals of color (Asian-American, Native America, Hispanic, and Black) with the specialized skills needed for this field which translates to social-economic empowerment for themselves and their families. As a key resource to the industry supporting a diverse pool of qualified young people, the BCA creates the opportunity to advance the growth of diversity from a grassroots and foundational level and serves an important niche. That is why BCA strives to increase programs through support so we may continue to provide educational information and industry exposure which will help individuals become valuable employees crucial to the continued growth of the culinary and hospitality industry today and the future. The BCA methodology of bridging foodservice and diversity excellence will also be the strategic platform and vehicle to introduce the importance of food sustainability, waste reduction, and health issues presently not being addressed in urban foodservice and communities. Please check out our website, www.bcaglobal.org for more information on our organization. Hours: 10-20 hours per week with flexible scheduling. Location: Office located on 37th St. between 5th and 6th. College Credit: We will cooperate with your school to help you attain credit for your internship. Skills: Should be literate in Microsoft Suite (primarily Word and Excel) Some experience with website maintenance preferred but not required Experienced with general website research Familiar and able to update social media (Facebook, Linked In, Twitter, Social Oomph, etc.) Able to assist management staff with daily/periodic projects Able to assist management with various aspects of event planning Comfortable with general administrative work (Correspondence, filing, answering phones, etc.) Able to assist in the development of our membership services Traits: Exceptional organizational skills Creative and innovative thinking; able to bring new ideas to our expanding organization Able to work well independently Pays strong attention to detail Interested, please send a detailed cover letter stating your qualifications and interest in the BCA as the e-mail body and a resume at info@bcaglobal.org

It is designed for students who are potential leaders displaying frequent disruptive behavior and declining academic proficiency. The curriculum is youth friendly, centered in play, music, movement, art and experiential learning. Please, send me an email at alex@nyunlockingfutures.org or give me call at (212) 791-4927 ext. 263. I will be happy to answer any questions. It is not required to have experience, training will be provided. Visit our website nyunlockingfutures.org

10018.description: Unlocking Futures is a not-for-profit, volunteer driven organization committed to transforming the chaotic lives of young people through persistent and compassionate mentoring. Our mission is to decrease the at-risk behavior of youth and to enhance the effectiveness of the people who live and work with them. New York Youth at Risk is looking for production volunteers to help throughout our organization, because the Production Team is truly what keeps our programs running. Being a production volunteer is extremely flexible, we work around YOUR schedule. We are looking for people who are ready to volunteer and support us with our events, making sure everything is running smoothly and ensuring we have a successful event. Visit our website nyunlockingfutures.org

10018.description: The Children’s Scholarship Fund (CSF) is looking for dedicated and enthusiastic young professionals, concerned about America’s education system and passionate about CSF’s mission, to join our Young Leaders Board. Despite recent education reforms, demand for CSF scholarships remains extremely high and is only growing. As we strive to serve this demand, CSF seeks to identify and cultivate the next generation of leaders committed to our continued success. A key to this effort is the Young Leaders Board, which works closely with CSF staff to grow the Young Leaders program and build awareness about CSF. Children’s Scholarship Fund (CSF): CSF aims to maximize educational opportunity for all children: for those in need by offering tuition assistance in grades K-8 for alternatives to faltering conventional schools, and for all children by supporting and cultivating education reform and parental choice efforts. Young Leaders Board: CSF Young Leaders Board seeks to maximize educational opportunities for all children by supporting CSF’s mission through a network of young professionals in NYC. The Young Leaders Board assists in fundraising, volunteer activities, and spreading awareness of CSF’s brand and objectives. Please contact Jane Lee at jlee@scholarshipfund.org for more information!
10018.title: Children's Scholarship Fund Seeking Young Leaders Board Members

10038.description: NYC Take Steps is the Foundation’s largest fundraising event in the nation. Help make our event a success. We’re making some great improvements to our festival, walk and finish areas. Share this special event with us! Nearly 1 in 200 Americans live each day with Crohn's disease or ulcerative colitis, life-changing digestive diseases. Living with these inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD) can be painful and isolating. The Crohn's & Colitis Foundation is dedicated to curing Crohn's and colitis, and to improving the quality of life of children and adults affected by these diseases. The Take Steps community also offers a safe, supportive environment for patients and families. Patients connect with others familiar with the ups and downs of IBD, as well as the friends who support their journey. The Foundation has invested almost $300 million in research to date, enabling groundbreaking treatments and greatly enhancing lives. Make a Difference Today! There are four shifts available: volunteers can take as many opportunities to contribute as they wish. Set-up: 11:00am - 5:00pm Unloading supplies Arrange barricades Decorations Signage Assist vendors Festival: 4:30pm - 9:00pm Festival Kick-off Kid Zone Distribute T-shirts, incentives, food informational materials Usher participants Walk Guide & Spirit Crew: 6:00pm - 8:00pm Event Breakdown: 8:00pm - 10:00pm We cannot make it happen without your help! Please contact us if you have more questions.
10038.title: NYC Take Steps for Crohn’s & Colitis - Thursday May 17, 2018 at Pier 16 at the South Street Seaport
10038.org: Crohn's & Colitis Foundation - Greater NY Chapter

10038.description: Join the American Lung Association as we raise awareness and funds to fight against lung cancer and for lung health. Together, we are a FORCE to be reckoned with. The American Lung Association is recruiting volunteers to help at the upcoming Lung Force Walk on Saturday, May 19, 2018. The event will be at South Street Seaport, Pier 16 New York, NY 10038. You can volunteer anywhere from 7:30 am until approximately 2:30 pm. We are unable to have a successful event without volunteers like you. Please reach out to me if you have any questions or concerns. Did you know? Lung cancer is the #1 cancer killer in America, and most people aren’t aware. Anyone can get it - if you have lungs, you can get lung cancer, and it’s on the rise in women. More than 33 million Americans suffer from asthma, COPD (which includes emphysema and chronic bronchitis), and other lung diseases.
10038.title: NYC Lung Force Walk

10038.description: About Reach the World is a New York City-based nonprofit organization that makes the benefits of travel accessible to classrooms, inspiring students to become curious, confident and compassionate global citizens. Every year since 2001, Reach the World has held an annual benefit to fundraise for the organization. The guest count is typically between 150 and 200 guests from diverse New York City and Connecticut-based industries. The event format includes cocktails, a silent auction, a sit-down dinner, and an award presentation at the end of the evening. This year's Cronkite Award will be given to a prominent honoree- stay tuned for the big reveal! The success of Reach the World's events are entirely dependent on the volunteer Benefit Committee members whose work and creativity make each event possible. Volunteering for RTW is a substantive way to gain event experience, network with other NYC professionals, and give back to a good cause. Reach the World welcomes all serious applicants to the 2018 Benefit Committee. The 2018 Benefit will take place on April 4 th, 2018 at the Boathouse in Central Park. To apply and for more information, please fill out this online application: https://www.tfaforms.com/4651651
10038.title: Join Reach the World's 2018 Annual Benefit Committee

10038.description: Do you have a passion for global education and international exchange? Do you believe in grassroots programs that leverage volunteer energies for a social good? Are you excited by events and production? Reach the World is seeking a mature volunteer looking to advance his/her networking, fundraising and event management skills for a 'team lead’ position of Reach the World’s 2018 Benefit Committee. This volunteer position (4-10h/week) reports to RTW's Development Manager. This position has a flexible start date between December 1, 2017 and January 2, 2018 and runs until the gala on April 6th 2018. The position is unpaid. The volunteer who secures the most donations receives two tickets to the event and is entered into the raffle! Responsibilities: Event Planning: Participate in bi-weekly evening meetings; lead the strategy for securing entertainment prize donations for the silent auction; manage other volunteers Outreach and Donor Management: Reach out to donors in person, through email and over the phone to secure a minimum of 25 entertainment prizes for the silent auction (tickets to sports, movies, theater; fitness classes; unique experiences); leverage network to increase donations; manage relationships with donors Gala Volunteering: Volunteer at the event (unless you plan to purchase a ticket and attend) Qualifications: Organized self-starter Fearless communicator Works well under pressure Team player Experience planning events and/or volunteering with a nonprofit is a bonus About Reach the World and the 2018 Annual Benefit Dinner Reach the World makes the benefits of travel accessible to classrooms, inspiring students to become curious, confident global citizens. Enabled by our virtual exchange platform, classrooms and volunteer travelers explore the world together. Every year since 2001, Reach the World has held an annual benefit to fundraise for the organization. The event includes cocktails, a silent auction, a sit-down dinner, and an award presentation at the end of the evening. This year's Cronkite Award will be given to a prominent honoree - stay tuned! The success of Reach the World's event is entirely dependent on the volunteer Benefit Committee members whose work and creativity make the event possible. Volunteering for RTW is a substantive way to gain event experience, network with other NYC professionals, and give back to a good cause. How to Apply Please submit a cover letter and resume by email to brianna@reachtheworld.org. No phone, email, mail, or fax inquiries will receive a response. Thank you for your interest in joining Reach the World on its exciting journey!
10038.title: Entertainment Prize Manager

10038.description: American Youth Table Tennis seeks interested college students in the New York City Metro Area to teach high school students the sport of table tennis, leadership, fair play, respect and teamwork. Table Tennis expertise required. As a volunteer coach you will receive a small per visit stipend per visit to cover transportation costs and effort. We will assign you to a New York City High School Table Tennis Program as an Assistant Table Tennis Coach. Duties will include, teaching basic and intermediate table tennis - footwork, serve, serve return, backhand, forehand, tactics, loop, loop drive as well as serving multi-ball and providing a positive and exciting framework for play, and dialog. American Youth Table Tennis and New York City Department of Education have teamed up to make this opportunity available to you. Table Tennis is an official varsity sport in New York City. We will be accepting applications in November and through to the end of January. We are in need of expert collegiate table tennis players to assist in selected High School Programs for the 2017-18 season which begins in December and Continues through March 2018 As an Assistant Coach, you will be giving back to the New York City community by imparting your table tennis knowledge on receptive and interested high school students. This program will look good on your resume and will help the next generation of collegiate table tennis players.
10038.title: Youth Table Tennis Coach - Collegiate Internship Program

The mentoring program is for males and females, but as of now, we do not have enough male mentors.

10038.description: Reading Partners needs volunteers like you to provide students in under-resourced elementary schools in your community with the proven, individualized reading support they need to read at grade level by fourth grade. Reading is the foundation for all future learning.The ability to read transforms lives and can empower children to reach their full potential. Research shows that when students can read at grade level by fourth grade, they have a greater opportunity to succeed in school and in life. With your help, we can equip students with the foundational skills they need to read at grade level. Each week, you will meet one-on-one with your student every week to help them develop strong literacy skills and discover a passion for reading. We'll provide a structured curriculum, in-person training, and ongoing support to help your student thrive. Rigorous research has proven that Reading Partners significantly increases reading proficiency. No teaching experience required and anyone over the age of 14 can volunteer. Flexible Monday to Thursday volunteer times between 9am and 5pm. Visit our website at www.readingpartners.org/volunteer to sign up and learn more.
10038.title: Become a reading partner- make a lifelong impact on a child (PS 126 Jacob August Riis, Manhattan)

10038.description: Our Junior Board is a unique way for young professionals, typically in their 20s and 30s, to help build the future of our overall organization. Becoming a member of the Junior Board is a way to ensure that our organization reflects a broad demographic, while developing the next generation of leaders. Through volunteer efforts, education, outreach and fundraising, the Junior Board has a measurable impact on our mission of providing health and human services to our select consumers. Each year, the Junior Board will select a focus for their efforts for the year, around which they will structure a fundraising initiative and hands-on volunteer activities. One of The URI Board’s Trustees serves as a mentor to the Junior Board -attending their meetings, acting as a general supporter of up-and-coming leadership, and serving as a formal liaison with the Board.

10038.description: The Events volunteer will report to and work closely with the Annual Giving & Special Projects Manager and the Resource Development team to plan, execute and manage the logistics around fundraising events. This volunteer position also requires the planning and execution of non-fundraising events including groundbreakings and home dedications. We are looking for a candidate who can focus specifically on building a structure for annual events as well as bring creative ideas to each project. Assist in the planning and execution of our annual fundraising event, The Habitat House Party Assist in the planning and execution of new events that will help cultivate new donors and sustain Habitat New York City contacts with existing donors and other key stakeholders. Such events include special build days like Broadway Builds, Women Build and more. Assist in the planning and execution of organization-wide events, including but not limited to groundbreakings, home dedications, and family and volunteer recognition events. Coordinate logistics for corporate team build days. Assist in Manage creative programming, operations, logistics, production, budgeting, contracts, billing and result reporting for all events. Create a working calendar of special events and a timeline for planning each even which includes budgets. Assist the Grants and In-Kind Manager in soliciting Gifts-in-Kind donations and sponsorships as needed for events. Work with the Communications and Marketing team to create event collateral and marketing materials for each event, as needed. Assist in the preparation for events including correspondence, invitations, guest lists, mailings, vendor approvals, ticketing, auction items, marketing materials and more. Continuously stays abreast of event strategies, ideas and trends in the marketplace including competitive and industry brands. Utilizes this knowledge to create opportunities and inform all facets of events Required Skills and Qualifications: Minimum 1-2 years event planning/event management experience specifically in New York City. College/University experience applies. Strong organizational and planning skills and the ability to think strategically and creatively. This includes database and budget management. Strong customer service including clients, donors, volunteers and vendors. Must be able to take direction, think creatively and proactively suggest solutions, and be able to prioritize tasks. Excellent communication skills (written and verbal) and presentation skills. Able to work nights and weekends as necessary. Bachelor’s degree or equivalent required. Ability to lift 30lbs. Passion and understanding of the Habitat for Humanity mission and the desire to promote it!
10038.title: Events Volunteer
10038.org: Habitat for Humanity New York City

This event lasts just 30 minutes, and will end at the NYC Rescue Mission at 90 Lafayette (Lafayette and White Street). Heavyweight: the average amount of food is 60-80 pounds. Divided between 5 people, each rescuer will carry about 15 lbs. Sign up directly on our website: Saturday 8/19/17 https://www.rescuingleftovercuisine.org/events/21409 Saturday 8/26/17 https://www.rescuingleftovercuisine.org/events/21410 Saturday 9/2/17 https://www.rescuingleftovercuisine.org/events/21411 Saturday 9/9/17 https://www.rescuingleftovercuisine.org/events/21412 Saturday 9/16/17 https://www.rescuingleftovercuisine.org/events/21413
10038.title: Fight Food Waste & Feed the Hungry in FiDi 4:30PM-5:00PM

10038.description: Sign your corporate group up for a volunteer event to rescue food for the hungry! During these events, your corporate group will travel to one or more of our food business partners that are ready to donate their excess food. The group then rescues this food and takes it to a nearby homeless shelter or soup kitchen. More details will be provided after contacted. SIGN UP FOR EVENTS DIRECTLY THROUGH OUR WEBSITE: Friday March 16th: https://www.rescuingleftovercuisine.org/events/31690 Monday March 19th: https://www.rescuingleftovercuisine.org/events/31515 Friday March 23rd: https://www.rescuingleftovercuisine.org/events/31691 Friday March 30th: https://www.rescuingleftovercuisine.org/events/31692 Monday April 2nd: https://www.rescuingleftovercuisine.org/events/31523 Friday April 6th: https://www.rescuingleftovercuisine.org/events/31693
10038.title: Corporate Group Volunteer Activity: Fight Food Waste and Feed the Hungry in Just 30 Minutes!

10038.description: Rescuing Leftover Cuisine is a nonprofit food rescue organization dedicated to reducing food waste and getting food to those in need. This is a perfect opportunity for college students are interested in the nonprofit sector, to volunteer to rescue food and help those in need. Sign up for events directly on our website: http://www.rescuingleftovercuisine.org/calendar
10038.title: Stop Food Waste and Feed the Hungry (College Students Looking to Give Back to the Community)

10038.description: The Next Chapter Book Club (NCBC) is an innovative community-based reading program for adolescents and adults with intellectual and developmental disabilities. The NCBC network includes more than 2,000 members meeting weekly since 2002 at nearly 300 book clubs in 31 states, four Canadian provinces, and three European countries. NCBC is the largest community-based book club program for adolescents and adults with intellectual and developmental disabilities in the world. It is an opportunity to maintain reading and literacy skills beyond school. Volunteers: We are looking for leaders to commit to one hour weekly, 11-12 or 12-1 any weekday, in the Bronx, Upper West Side, and Upper East Side, for a minimum of 14 weeks.
10038.title: Next Chapter Book Club (NCBC)

10038.description: Help your community to stop food waste and fight hunger by bringing excess food to homeless shelters. You will be taking bags of excess food, which would have been thrown out by the restaurant, to the nearest homeless shelter. This is a great opportunity to gain community service experience while helping others at the same time!!!! Please sign up for events directly on our website: http://www.rescuingleftovercuisine.org/calendar
10038.title: Stop Food Waste and Help Feed the Hungry This Holiday Season!!! (Great Way To Give Back)

10038.description: I-PREP (Interview, Practice and Review for Emerging Professionals): Work one-on-one to help people supported by AHRC gain confidence and sharpen their employment interview skills. Each hour and a half session provides them with two 30 minute mock interviews and feedback, and training for the volunteers. MONEY MAKES SENSE: Teach financial literacy skills to people supported by AHRC who need to understand how to save money. During a two hour workshop, volunteers work one-on-one with them to help improve their budgeting skills, understand credit, and increase their savings.
10038.title: I-PREP and Money Makes Sense

10038.description: Revitalize community spaces throughout New York City with Habitat for Humanity! Our Brush With Kindness (BWK) program enhances community spaces in all five boroughs by painting interiors and murals, landscaping and gardening, and performing minor construction tasks in public schools, playgrounds, community centers, and public parks. As a volunteer, you will have the opportunity to create your own schedule, meet new people, learn new skills, and most importantly, make a positive difference in the lives of others. No experience is necessary - just enthusiasm! Our sites are open Wednesday through Saturday 9:00AM - 4:00PM. Volunteers ages 14 - 17 may participate with a signed waiver from a parent or guardian. How to Sign Up: Learn more before signing up by visiting our website (habitatnyc.org) OR create a profile on volunteerhub and sign up for a volunteer orientation (see instructions below). Please note: orientations are optional and are not required for Brush with Kindness or Construction volunteers. If you are ready to start making a difference, follow the steps below to create your volunteerhub account: 1. Log on to habitatnyc.volunteerhub.com 2. Click the \"Create an Account\" button to create a new profile Choose a username and password Leave the Join Code field blank and click \"Next\" Input your full name, contact information, date of birth, and emergency contact's information 3. Select \"Construction\" and click on the event that interests you 4. Click on the \"Sign Up\" button and follow the directions to register for the event 5. You will receive a confirmation email letting you know you successfully signed up for a volunteer day! Please email volunteer@habitatnyc.org with any questions
10038.title: Paint with Habitat for Humanity NYC!
10038.org: Habitat for Humanity New York City

10038.description: HFH NYC seeks a highly motivated and compassionate individual to work with partner families in areas such as sweat equity, homeownership education, and adjustment to new responsibility. The position’s primary importance is to support the Partner Family by empowering them through homeownership. RESPONSIBILITIES The position's primary responsibility is to engage future Habitat for Humanity New York City Family Partners through phone call follow up; email inquiry response; database management; answer questions about the Habitat home ownership program, the application. and selection process. * Explain the homeownership program * Describe the family partner selection process and timeline * Coordinate and schedule Information session attendance; open house attendance; panel interviews and 1-on-1 meetings * Perform such other tasks as may be needed or requested to facilitate a positive customer experience at Habitat-NYC * Perform other general office and administrative duties as directed by the Family Services team * Provide general assistance to customers, answering questions, and directing customers to the correct department
10038.title: Family Services Office Volunteer
10038.org: Habitat for Humanity New York City

10038.description: Every other Monday evening from 6:00-8:00 p.m. fresh art has a sewing group that hand sews sock monkeys. The monkeys are sold via fresh art's website as well as select craft fairs to benefit the organizations fine arts programming for New York City artists with special needs. Knowledge of hand sewing is necessary and participants must be a minimum of 21 years of age. We provide all of the sewing materials. It takes about four-six hours to sew a sock monkey so we ask that you would come to at least two to three sessions in order to finish a monkey. If you wish to continue with the group, that would be great. We have volunteers who have been with us for many years. Please look at the website for fresh art's history of what we do: www.freshartnyc.org Volunteers also help with staffing at the two-three craft fairs fresh art participates in per year for selling the sock monkeys and at the organizations yearly benefit. For further information about the group and upcoming sewing dates, please contact our Volunteer Coordinator : Heber Sanchez: freshartvolunteercoordinator@gmail.com
10038.title: sewing volunteers

10118.description: Join us to help rescue leftovers from a cafeteria in the Empire State Building! This event will end at BRC, located at 127 W 25th St, New York, NY 10001. Medium to heavy weight - the average amount of food rescued from this event is 35-65 pounds.
10118.title: End Food Waste in Midtown Fridays at 3PM!

10118.description: Be our community champion! Community Options seeks business people to help further its mission. Among the goals set for the Business Advisory Council, or COBAC: To assist Community Options staff in its fundraising endeavors, To assist Community Options staff in networking with the business community, To help individuals with disabilities integrate into their communities, To ensure utmost quality in Community Options services, To educate local business owners and the corporate sector about persons with disabilities and the role that the business community can play in their lives, To attain a societal understanding and acceptance of a person with a disability as a productive member of the community. As a member of COBAC in your community, you're our champion! Join us today. Learn more about COBAC here: http://www.comop.org/get-involved/cobac/
10118.title: Business Advisory Council Committee - NYC

10013.description: Every summer CMP acts as an official provider for the Summer Youth Employment Program (SYEP), a program that connects youth aged 16-24 to employment opportunities across the city. This summer CMP is expected to assist 700 youth in gaining work experience, developing their financial literacy and exploring future careers. You can learn more about the program here: http://www1.nyc.gov/site/dycd/index.pageThis service opportunity will help summer job-seeking youth in filling out the SYEP Application interviewing them and helping them a select an ideal work site where they can learn and grow. Responsibilities Attend volunteer orientation and learn about the enrollment process. Develop an understanding of assigned participating work sites. Get to know the candidates educational background, career goals and interests. Match candidates to an appropriate work site. Qualifications: Strong communication skills. Organized and can complete enrollment process in a timely manner. Previous experience working with young adults is a plus. Time frame: Tentative Dates: first two weekends of April 4/7, 4/8, 4/14 and 4/15 Time: 9am-5pm Dates and times are flexible based on the volunteer’s availability. Benefits: Free lunch provided on day of enrollment. Opportunity to give back to the community and make professional connections.
10013.title: SYEP Job Interviewer

10013.description: We are having our annual gala on April 12th and need volunteers to help check guests in, collect donations, greet guests, and do other miscellaneous tasks (we have servers, etc.). This is a terrific opportunity for those interested in photography, human rights, diversity, etc!
10013.title: Spring Gala 2018

10013.description: For many new immigrants, learning English is a first step to full participation in American society. Help them take that first step by becoming a volunteer teacher in English or Citizenship classes. English classes help students improve their communication skills. Citizenship classes help students prepare for the U.S. citizenship test. Volunteers work in teams to plan lessons and teach the class. This fun and rewarding experience gives you a chance to make a difference in the lives of others. Individuals with an interest in education careers are encouraged to apply. Requirements Must have good communication skills and a strong desire to help and work with new immigrants Prior teaching experience is preferred. Bilingual skills are a plus. We prefer volunteers who can commit to teaching at least two semesters Prospective volunteers must complete application and be interviewed. Volunteer Schedule: 9:30 am-11:30am (Tues or Thurs) 10:30 am-12:30 pm (Tues or Thurs) 1pm to 4pm (Saturday) 6:30pm to 8:30 pm (Mon, Tues or Wed) Spring 2018 - February 27, 2018 to June 7, 2018 Summer 2018 - July 9, 2018 to August 18, 2018 Prospective volunteers must complete application and will be interviewed. Please contact us at cpanyc@cpanyc.org for an application OR apply on-line here: http://bit.ly/volunteerteacherapplication For more information: http://bit.ly/VolunteerToTeachEnglishorCitizenshipClass
10013.title: Teach English or Citizenship Class in Chinatown

10013.description: Help rescue catered lunch leftovers from 2 offices in Greenwich Village! We will deliver the food to NYC Rescue Mission, located at 90 Lafayette St, New York, NY 10013. Mediumweight: the average amount of food rescued from this event is 25-50 pounds.
10013.title: Fight Food Waste in Greenwich on Fridays 3:30PM!

10013.description: VOLUNTEER NEEDED FOR OUR MANHATTAN OFFICE INSIDE OF FEDCAP. DUTIES: --Greet the client --Explain that we take pictures and they have to sign a waiver [(we can cut their heads off on the picture, should they not want to be seen) Not mandatory for receiving services] --Measure assist them in tying a tie (if they do not know how) finding a suit, shirt, slacks, shoes, etc. that fits. (They can try on the clothing in the restroom.) --Arrange for the hemming of pants or the sewing on of buttons with the tailor and set a date for the client to pick up the tailored items. If no alterations are needed, then fold up the items and place in a bag for the client. --Keep records of activities and calls in the log. --Be able to work alone, with minimal supervision or with others We are doing one day a week, for now (date to be discussed), but the time will be 10 AM to 3 PM. This is a great opportunity for anyone wanting to go into law enforcement and who wants to see \"the other side\" after a person comes home, someone that wants to be in the fashion industry, or social services/non-profit sector. You will be networking with everyday people, politicians, individuals from different programs (formerly incarcerated individuals, etc.), City organizations/programs, and pastors. There is a possibility that you will be helping with administrative work and our events as well. You must be neat and presentable. We also will need you to assist in pop-up shops and the occasional donation pick up. Check out what we do to get a better feel for 100 Suits http://www.100suits.org/100-suits-speaks Please be reliable! SERIOUS INQUIRIES ONLY!!!
10013.title: Fashion and Justice Volunteer (Queens)

10013.description: Lenox Hill Neighborhood House, widely recognized as one of New York's premier human services providers, is a 123-year-old settlement house that provides an extensive array of effective and integrated services which significantly improve the lives of 15,000 people in need each year on the East Side of Manhattan. Our Senior Center at East 54th Street and Lexington Avenue is a vibrant program that provides hundreds of older adults with educational, cultural, health and social activities every week. We are seeking instructors for a variety of classes and activities including: Zumba Chair Yoga Mah Jong Line Dancing Conversational Italian Book Discussion Group Digital Photography Instructors lead their respective classes/activities once per week on weekdays. If you have one of the skills above and are interested in sharing your time and knowledge with active and enthusiastic older adults please contact Anthony Snowden, Volunteer Director at asnowden@lenoxhill.org or 212-218-0487.
10013.title: Instructor for Senior Center

10013.description: Every year CMP, (formerly known as the Chinatown Manpower Project) hosts our annual Career Building Awards Gala, recognizing leaders in their respective fields. This year we will be honoring individuals of the Food Service Industry. This gala acts as a major fundraiser to support our programs and services that provide economic empowerment and encourage economic self-sufficiency. We will need about 3 volunteers to assist the Silent Auction, a key component of our Gala. Prior to the gala we will need volunteers to pack and label silent auction items, and the day of place and distribute items to auctions winners. Looking for volunteers who enjoy working with people and can think on their feet.
10013.title: Gala Silent Auction Volunteer

10013.description: In preparation for our annual Career Building Awards Gala, CMP is seeking 2 volunteers to translate a few short articles and items for our silent auction from Chinese to English. Interested volunteers should send a short writing sample with a document translated from Chinese to English. Volunteer service can be completed digitally.
10013.title: Chinese to English Document Translator

10013.description: Are you an Accounting major with a passion for nonprofit work? The CMP, formerly known as the Chinatown Manpower Project is seeking an intern to assist our fiscal director in managing multiple budgets for our services and programs. Schedule will be flexible and intern will be expected to dedicate one to two days a week for a few hours.
10013.title: Non-Profit Accounting Intern

10013.description: Ardea Arts is a non-profit production and development company dedicated to creating and performing new opera and music-theater works. Our goal is to create work that brings new audiences, and to engage people far outside the walls of the opera house. We work with exciting, unexpected artists who speak to audiences through the media of opera: music, words, theater, and visuals. We strive to involve the community to the greatest extent possible in the process and performance of our works. Our work would not be possible without strong volunteer support. Our volunteers come from all walks of life and from diverse socioeconomic, religious, and ethnic backgrounds. From seasonal to year-round opportunities, there are many ways to volunteer at Ardea Arts. Volunteering for Ardea Arts offers opportunities for individuals and groups to enhance a variety of production, administrative and customer service skills. Volunteers receive invitations to exclusive volunteer-only events, and exposure to the workings of one of the most vibrant boutique development and production companies in the opera-musical industry.
10013.title: Volunteer for Ardea Arts!

10013.description: VOLUNTEER NEEDED FOR OUR MANHATTAN OFFICE. DUTIES: --Greet the client --Explain that we take pictures and they have to sign a waiver [(we can cut their heads off on the picture, should they not want to be seen) Not mandatory for receiving services] --Measure assist them in tying a tie (if they do not know how) finding a suit, shirt, slacks, shoes, etc. that fits. (They can try on the clothing in the restroom.) --Arrange for the hemming of pants or the sewing on of buttons with the tailor and set a date for the client to pick up the tailored items. If no alterations are needed, then fold up the items and place in a bag for the client. --Keep records of activities and calls in the log. --Be able to work alone, with minimal supervision or with others We are doing one day a week, for now (date to be discussed), but the time will be 10 AM to 3 PM. This is a great opportunity for anyone wanting to go into law enforcement and who wants to see \"the other side\" after a person comes home, someone that wants to be in the fashion industry, or social services/non-profit sector. You will be networking with everyday people, politicians, individuals from different programs (formerly incarcerated individuals, etc.), City organizations/programs, and pastors. There is a possibility that you will be helping with administrative work and our events as well. You must be neat and presentable. We also will need you to assist in pop-up shops and the occasional donation pick up. Check out what we do to get a better feel for 100 Suits http://www.100suits.org/100-suits-speaks Please be reliable! SERIOUS INQUIRIES ONLY!!!
10013.title: Fashion And Justice Volunteers Needed

10013.description: SHOVELING HELP NEEDED THIS WINTER! PSNYC is looking for help shoveling its playing field this Winter! WHEN: as needed after snowfall, whatever dates you are available (as quickly as possible after a snowfall, we want to prevent field from icing over) WHERE: James J. Walker Park Field, located in the west village of Manhattan at Clarkson St & Hudson St, New York NY 10013. Nearest subways: A/B/C/D/E to W 4th; 1 train to Houston St. INTERESTED? Please contact us at info@psnyc.org and write \"snow shoveling help\" in the subject. PSNYC / Pickup Soccer NYC is a non-profit soccer organization registered in the State of New York. Games are held year-round at fields across NYC. Additional informational can be found at http://pickupsoccer.org and http://pickupsoccer.org/summary.
10013.title: Park Snow Shovelers needed!

10013.description: This opportunity is available every Monday from 10-10:30 AM! Help us rescue excess catered food from a catering company in Greenpoint! We're saving this food from the trash and delivering it to Northside Senior Center (179 N 6th St in Williamsburg). This event will last about 30 minutes. Mediumweight: the average amount of food is around 20-30 lbs. SIGN UP DIRECTLY ON OUR WEBSITE: Monday February 26th: https://www.rescuingleftovercuisine.org/events/31005 Monday March 5th: https://www.rescuingleftovercuisine.org/events/31006 Monday March 12th: https://www.rescuingleftovercuisine.org/events/31007 Monday March 19th: https://www.rescuingleftovercuisine.org/events/31008 Monday March 26th: https://www.rescuingleftovercuisine.org/events/31009 Monday April 2nd: https://www.rescuingleftovercuisine.org/events/31010
10013.title: Fight Food Waste & Feed the Hungry in Greenpoint 10AM-10:30AM

10013.description: Go the extra mile with Back on My Feet NYC! Dedicated teams of volunteers run 2-4 miles with our members who are transitioning out of homelessness. We encourage runners of all speeds (run/jog/walk) to become a part of our community! Team City Hall runs with the NYC Rescue Mission at the NW corner of Collect Pond Park every Monday, Wednesday, and Friday from 5:45-6:45AM. To find out more and sign up for an orientation, visit nyc.backonmyfeet.org/nyc-run-with-us
10013.title: Downtown Morning Runner

10012.description: There’s never a dull moment here at Housing Works, between our annual benefits such as Design on a Dime, weekly Thrift Shop sales, and a wide array of events at our beloved Bookstore Cafe - we have a plethora of exciting and unique happenings to keep you busy all year long! Many of these events need extra support, including our annual Best of Spring sale. Volunteers will have an opportunity to support our staff in set up and clean up, as well as as customers shop our best donations of the season all throughout March! Almost every one of our eleven thrift shops will be holding a Best of Spring, which means we need tons of volunteers throughout the month! This is a great opportunity for those interested in retail, sales, and fashion merchandising and is a perfect opportunity for groups up to 5 people. For more details about the event, please visit our event page: https://www.housingworks.org/events For a list of our store locations, please visit https://www.housingworks.org/businesses Email Ida at volunteer@housingworks.org for more details, as there are many shifts across our shops.
10012.title: Support Housing Works at Best of Spring!

10012.description: Rescue catered leftovers from 2 offices in SoHo! This event will end at Bowery Mission, located at 227 Bowery, New York, NY 10002. Medium weight: the average amount of food rescued from this event is 30-50 pounds.
10012.title: Fight Hunger is Soho Fridays 3:30PM!

10012.description: NYU has some delicious catering every other week. We need volunteers to pick up this catering and deliver it to a nearby shelter. Heavy pickup: 15-90 pounds
10012.title: Assist NYU in the Fight Against Food Waste Fridays 3:30PM!

10012.description: Housing Works is powered by a vibrant community of volunteers who lend their time, dedication, and passion to many different roles within our organization. For more information about our mission and programs, visit our website: www.housingworks.org We are looking for one individual to support our volunteer coordinator in volunteer recruitment, management, and training. Be a part of one of Housing Works' biggest fundraising events of the year, Design on a Dime, while improving your administrative skills and supporting our volunteer recruitment efforts! The individual will support the volunteer coordinator by doing the following: Researching and recruiting groups and individuals that may be interested in volunteering at our annual Design on a Dime Basic data entry (Salesforce CRM) Answering emails and calls professionally and promptly Administrative task as needed Committing to about 5-10 hours a week Must be available to provide support the final week of April If interested, please email Ida at volunteer@housingworks.org with \"Data Entry Volunteer\" as subject line. Please include resume as an attachment. You must send an email to be considered; requests via VolunteerMatch will not be accepted. Must be 18 or older.
10012.title: Volunteer Recruitment Opportunity!

10012.description: Housing Works is powered by a vibrant community of volunteers who lend their time, dedication, and passion to many different roles within our organization. For more information about our mission and programs, visit our website: www.housingworks.org Be a part of one of Housing Works' biggest fundraising events of the year, Design on a Dime while improving your administrative skills and gaining customer service experience! Responsibilities and Duties Researching and making outgoing donation and/or cold calls to obtain products for upcoming event Basic data entry (Salesforce CRM) Answering emails and calls professionally and promptly Administrative task as needed Excellent phone and computer skills a plus. If interested, please email Ida at volunteer@housingworks.org with \"Data Entry Volunteer\" as subject line. Please include resume as an attachment.
10012.title: Design on a Dime Data Entry Volunteer

10012.description: Housing Works is powered by a vibrant community of volunteers who lend their time, dedication, and passion to many different roles within our organization. For more information about our mission and programs, visit our website: www.housingworks.org If you are interested in this opportunity, please email Beatrice Calderon at s.calderon@housingworks.org. Include \"Data Entry Volunteer\" in subject line, as well as a resume as an attachment. The Data Entry Volunteer will provide support to the Asset Protection Manager with assistance in Customer Service Database entry. · Prepare, compile and sort documents for data entry · Ensure accurate data has been entered in database · Verify data and correct data where necessary · Update data and delete unnecessary information · Check completed work for accuracy and make any required changes immediately · Assist in developing and maintaining records within the database system Qualifications/Requirements If you have any of these qualities or skills listed below, then this would be a great opportunity for you: · High School Diploma or Higher · Great communication skills · Great organizational skills · Attention to detail · Ability to analyze data · Proficiency in data entry · Any availability between 10 am and 5 pm: Monday-Friday. · Minimum commitment of 4 hours a week
10012.title: Data Entry Volunteer

10012.description: Housing Works is powered by a vibrant community of volunteers who lend their time, dedication, and passion to many different roles within our non-profit organization. By volunteering, you are directly responsible for providing funding to and advocating for New Yorkers affected by homelessness and HIV/AIDS. We’re always on the lookout for dynamic and friendly people to help provide great customer service and an outstanding experience within our thrift shops. Each volunteer is trained to have the knowledge needed, and each person’s volunteer experience can be tailored to their personal skills and interests. Do you have special skills or interests in any of the areas below? Let us know when you sign up! Art Antiques/Vintage Books Customer Service Home Decor Jewelry Media Merchandising Please visit our website to find one of our 12 locations: https://www.housingworks.org/businesses Qualifications/Requirements Attend Info Session/Interview with Volunteer Program Manager Must be 16 and over to apply independently. People aged 14 and 15 must obtain working papers from their school and parent’s permission before attending a session. Complete in-store orientation and training after completing Info Session/Interview Strong interest in the HW mission to end the dual crises of homelessness and HIV/AIDS Commitment to excellent customer service Excellent communications skills (both verbal and written), interpersonal and team-oriented skills Self-starting, self motivating mindset Attention to detail Basic mathematical skills to include adding, subtracting, multiplying, dividing, and calculating percentages Flexibility in schedule Ability to stand, walk, kneel, and bend for long periods of time and lift up to 40 pounds
10012.title: Join Housing Works as a Thrift Shop Volunteer or Intern!

10012.description: If you love helping people find that perfect thrift-store treasure, or you want a chance to give back to your community while gaining some great retail experience, help us on the sales floor at one of our ten upscale thrift shops! We are looking for dynamic and friendly people to run the register and back counter, assist in the fitting rooms, refill and straighten up racks, and help the staff with a wide variety of projects. Qualified volunteers possess the ability to communicate respectfully and effectively with staff, customers, and other volunteers. You should also have a passion for good organization and a willingness to take on new challenges! We have stores in Brooklyn Heights, Tribeca, SoHo, the West Village, Gramercy, Chelsea, Upper East Side, Upper West Side, Yorkville, and a new location in Hell's Kitchen. Check out http://www.housingworks.org/locations/category/thrift-shops/ for addresses. Apply online at http://www.housingworks.org/volunteer.
10012.title: Want to use your retail skills to support a good cause? Join our team of thrift shop volunteers!

10012.description: We are recruiting new members for our Advisory Board of civic, business, community, and philanthropic leaders. The advisory board services in an advisory capacity only, not a fiduciary capacity. Advisory Board Members are knowledgeable about The Trust for Public Land both on the local and national level; act as ambassadors and key connectors to promote programs and seek additional donors to support The Trust for Public Land’s work in New York. We want members who are highly motivated by our mission to connect people to nature by creating parks and protecting land! Please include your Profession, Company Name, Title, and what Boards if any, you currently serve on when applying. Thank you.
10012.title: New York Advisory Board

10012.description: Esperanza is dedicated to keeping young people at home with their families. We work to safely reduce reliance on out-of-home placement for court-involved youth by offering a community-based alternative to incarceration throughout the five boroughs of New York City. Esperanza began delivering direct services in 2002 and currently serves young people who are prosecuted in Family Court as well as youth who are being prosecuted as adults in Supreme/Criminal Court. Our home-based, direct-service program includes up to six months of intensive therapy for youth and their families, as well as case and crisis management. Towards the end of this period, some of our participants are matched with mentors for a period of time to further support the work they have done while in Esperanza. Esperanza NY, Inc. is looking for individuals to mentor youth. Interested applicants must have a passion for working with young people and the ability to build positive relationships with them. This is a volunteer opportunity.
10012.title: Mentor

10012.description: Muslim Community Network is seeking volunteers to help coordinate the logistics and successful implementation of our monthly Community Education Workshops. Volunteers will be expected to help set up the event space (set up folding tables and chairs, etc.), greet attendees with a smile and cheerful attitude, register attendees and assist with clean up after the event. The workshops are held once a month on a weekend during the afternoon. Information about our Community Education program is available here: http://mcnny.org/community-education/ Volunteers are welcome to volunteer at subsequent workshops and can be notified of additional dates. Requirements: Great interpersonal skills A commitment to social justice and interfaith dialogue Punctual and reliable To apply click here to visit our volunteer application form: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfxPRM5KO4JP9i6kxZ02rt3eV0PJS8g6-CNzCstQEl--8S2Ig/viewform?usp=sf_link
10012.title: Community Education Workshop Volunteer

10012.description: This opportunity is available 7-7:30 PM every Mon-Fri! Excess bread can be combined with other ingredients to create meals to feed the hungry at a nearby food pantry rather than being thrown out. Help us walk with the food that would have been thrown away! We will get bags of bread and walk for this 30 minute event, and will finish at the Bowery Mission at 227 Bowery. Light Weight: the average total amount of food is 15-20 lbs. Sign up directly on our website; http://www.rescuingleftovercuisine.org/calendar
10012.title: Stop Food Waste & Feed the Hungry in Greenwich Village!

10012.description: Housing Works is powered by a vibrant community of volunteers who lend their time, dedication, and passion to many different roles within our organization. For more information about our mission and programs, visit our website: www.housingworks.org Join our team of volunteer Bookstore Sales Associates! Our bookstore serves many purposes for the community and with that, our volunteers enjoy a wide variety of responsibilities. Bookstore Sales Associates price and shelve books, run the register, take donations, maintain sections and displays, and help customers. You act as the friendly face that keeps customers coming back and supporting the Housing Works mission! Bookstore Volunteers are frequently asked to support us at exciting special events held at the Bookstore, such as concerts, book launches, and trivia events. Volunteer Requirements * Complete an online application. 10012.description: ABOUT MUSLIM COMMUNITY NETWORK : The Muslim Community Network is a 501(c)3 non-profit organization that identifies and cultivates the leadership skills of all Americans to fully participate in the social landscape. MCN’s strategies include creating strong relationships with other faith-based communities; articulating and advancing an understanding of the need for citizen engagement; developing the skills and ability of our community to affect change; and building the next generation’s identity and capacity as leaders. HOURS : Flexible. Estimate a 5- 10 hour/week commitment GENERAL RESPONSIBILITIES : MCN is seeking a community service coordinator to support staff in planning, organizing and executing upcoming community service opportunities including the Thanksgiving Food Baskets Pack-a-thon, the Bellevue Dinner Drop off to NICU and PICU families , and Ramadan Food Baskets and Eid Toy Drive events. The coordinator will lead research of food and supply procurement for activities, create purchase orders, plan logistics and coordinate outreach to volunteers. RELEVANT EXPERIENCE: Ideally, experience working with volunteers, volunteer organizations and/or active in community service activities. SKILLS : Demonstrated capability to effectively communicate orally and in writing. Ability to work well with a diverse group of staff and volunteers. Ability to effectively manage a wide array of tasks, projects, and responsibilities Ability to work productively with minimal supervision. Proficient in basic computer applications and internet technology, such as MS Office and Google Drive. Must have excellent organizational skills with attention to detail. Ability to set priorities, multitask, and meet deadlines. HOW TO APPLY: Click here for MCN’s volunteer application .
10012.title: Community Service Coordinator

10012.description: Come volunteer in rural Kenya with one of our 4 humanitarian aid programs: (1) Healthcare, (2) HIV/AIDS Education, (3) Education, (4) Microenterprise Development. Volunteer Kenya - ICODEI is a non-religious, non-political volunteer organization run through a partnership of past overseas volunteers and local Kenyans. Our Microenterprise Development Program is our newest program. We have been active in helping set up small income-generating activities (IGA) for rural self-help groups since the early 2000's (primarily thru grants), but only recently began focusing our work on providing more advice, consulting assistance, and small loans to the groups. MDP volunteers work with the existing microenterprise groups to help them grow and improve their existing projects, as well as help newly forming groups start an IGA. The 5 main areas of volunteer activity in the MDP are as follows: • Progress Assessment • Facilitate a Group Project Discussion / Evaluation and Provide Project Advice • Facilitate Knowledge and Resource Sharing Within the Network of Groups • Provide Small Loans • Provide General Business Skills Training Seminars Most volunteers spend their time doing a combination of all the above 5 items. Our value-added is not just in the form of providing financial resources (loans) but includes project planning advice, basic management and accounting training, and (very importantly) volunteers act as facilitators between our vast network of groups in order to facilitate knowledge and resource sharing among the groups. Our pilot microlending program has just gotten off the ground during the last several months and we currently have about $10,000 USD in outstanding loans. The MDP volunteers will be spending a lot of their time over the next several months meeting with the loans groups to ensure that are on schedule with paying back their loans and that they are investing their money prudently (e.g., in productivity enhancing resources versus consumption items). As the loans are repaid, the volunteers then give them out in the form of new loans to other groups. We have a very large backlog of loan application requests. As a volunteer in the MDP you would spend the vast majority of your time out in the field meeting and working with the women microenterprise groups, which is a very rewarding and educational experience. All of the microenterprise groups within our network are independent groups. We do not manage their day to day operations and do not charge any type of fee for our services. We are a strict volunteer non-for-profit organization. All interest that we receive from the microloans goes towards new loans for additional groups. We are now have a network of around 100 microenterprise groups within the western Kenya region. As of June 2007, our organization has had over 350 volunteers since 1998 from over 6 different countries. Volunteers in our Microenterprise Development have come from a variety of backgrounds including undergrad business students (Duke, Rice, Miami, Indiana), MBA and graduate students on their summer break (Stanford, Penn, etc.), management consultants (BCG, McKinsey, CRA), retired professionals, and accountants. Check out our website at www.volunteerkenya.org
10012.title: Microenterprise Development in Africa

10012.description: Volunteers help seniors with shopping or errands, accompany them to the doctor or other appointments, provide a steady arm to lean on, as well as moral support. Internships are available for high school and college students on a year round basis. Many schools participate in VN's Intergenerational Program, where students learn valuable job skills and life lessons, improving their self - esteem and sense of responsibility.

10012.description: During the warmer months, some of our programs like to provide roof top barbecues for their clients. At other times throughout the year, another provides a special monthly Candlelight Dinner, bringing the food to the tables, serving the residents in a â restaurant styleâ environment. Whatever the occasion, we always try to provide opportunities for our clients to socialize and eat. In order to provide this very special service, we need enthusiastic, friendly volunteers who can act as servers, busboys, waiters and more. Locations vary throughout the city.

10012.description: Volunteers are matched with homebound, isolated and lonely seniors whom they visit at least once each week. Many volunteers supplement with a phone call on another day just to see how their senior is doing. Schedules are very flexible, visits can take place during the daytime, evenings or weekends.

10036.description: The Children’s Tumor Foundation is the leading nonprofit funding source of NF (neurofibromatosis) research in the world. In a few short years, we have grown from a foundation that funds promising science to one that catalyzes the drug discovery process through a series of innovative processes, key partnerships and strategic investments. Do you enjoy helping to raise money for a good cause? We are looking for dedicated volunteers to help organize and execute our new and exciting 5K National Tour that is coming to New York on April 15, 2018! Event website: https://join.ctf.org/event/i-know-a-fighter-5k-new-york-city-2018/e158594 Volunteer Sign up: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSe15fflYulmmv4CgIxi9C1FXbvei77zazstCq2436jpbzIF5Q/viewform

10036.description: We are in need of a panel of Industry experts in the fields of Science, Technology, Engineering Arts, Math (STEAM) to inspire, motivate, educate students to enter these fields. You will be part of a panel of five or six people speaking about your career and how it relates to STEAM. Students will then be able to ask questions of you. You will need to commit your morning from 9-11 if selected.
10036.title: We Connect The Dots Discovery Day 2018 - Panel Speakers

10036.description: We Connect The Dots' (WCTD) Discovery Day highlights the endless career possibilities offered through careers in STEAM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Arts, Math) and also showcases the programs we offer through out the year. What will be expected of me as a volunteer? As a volunteer, you would be expected to help and mentor students by being interactive and supportive during the program when the students need help by having the opportunity to learn how to inspire students to be life-long learners. Some of the examples you may be assigned to do is mentoring students, registration, giving tours of the facility, setting up and cleaning up before and after the program. Do I need any special skills? No, you do not need to have any special skills. Our program incorporates a variety of team building activities that support our goal to engage students to work collaboratively. The result is that by volunteering you will benefit from the experience and come away with valuable skills. To learn more about the opportunity reach out to our team at events@we-connect-the-dots.org, to learn more about the program please visit our website at http://we-connect-the-dots.org/discoveryday2018/ Shifts: (any or all) Monday, April 16th 8:00 am - 3:30 pm Tuesday, April 17th 8:00 am - 3:30 pm Wednesday, April 18th 8:00 am - 3:30 pm
10036.title: Do you enjoy learning along side students?  WCTD's Discovery Day starts the journey.

10036.description: Come join us as we educate children about healthy eating, food, and taste. Training Dates: Monday, February 26th, 5:30 PM Wednesday, February 28th, 12:00 PM What is Spoons Across America? Spoons Across America (SAA) is a not-for-profit organization dedicated to educating children, teachers, and families about the benefits of healthy eating though food and nutrition-based educational programs for children. What is Agriculture Literacy Week? Spoons Across America is the primary New York City implementer of Cornell Cooperative Extension’s New York Agriculture Literacy Week. In this free program for New York City schools, 1st and 2nd graders learn about New York state agriculture - what kinds of food are grown and produced in the state, and the people who are involved in growing and producing them. Spoons Across America trains volunteers to read a selected storybook and lead a related curriculum activity. Between March 12 and April 25, 2018, volunteers will read Before We Eat: From Farm to Table by Pat Brisson. Students will be taken on the journey from farm to table to understand different aspects of agriculture and the many possible careers involved. This is a captivating glimpse of what it takes to bring the food we eat to us in order to nourish our bodies and spirits. What do Volunteers do? After participating in a hands-on training, volunteers participate in and lead all aspects of Agriculture Literacy Week implementation. Volunteer responsibilities include reading the Agriculture Literacy Week book aloud to the class, leading an activity related to the book, and set up and clean up. We are looking for individuals enthusiastic about healthy eating and children’s programming to join us! Volunteer Training: All volunteers receive training at the Spoons Across America offices (630 Ninth Avenue @ 44th Street in Manhattan), and are required to attend one of the following training dates: Monday, February 26th, 5:30 PM Wednesday, February 28th, 12:00 PM **** Do you work for a business or company that wants to make a volunteer commitment? We can schedule a special training session for groups of 10 or more people, onsite or at our offices. Contact Ali for more information. When do your programs take place? Agriculture Literacy Week programs occur DURING SCHOOL HOURS. Please be advised that there are no after-work hours available for Agriculture Literacy Week. I'm ready to go! How do I sign up? If you are interested in volunteering with Spoons Across America this year, please contact Ali McDowell, Director of Programs and Partnerships, at ali@spoonsacrossamerica.org. In your email, please indicate which training session you will attend: Monday, February 26th at 5:30 PM or Wednesday, February 28th at 12:00 PM. * Please note: Volunteers must complete a background check prior to the program date.
10036.title: New York Agriculture Literacy Week - join us in the classroom!
10036.org: From Farm to Table d/b/a Spoons Across America

10036.description: Do you want to transform the lives of youth and poor communities using the developmental power of performance? Everyday at All Stars, we help young people develop both on stage and off. We do this through six programs, including the All Stars Talent Show Network and the Development School for Youth. Our volunteers come from various professions and personal backgrounds - but what they have in common is the belief that all people should develop in their lives. Our programs enable this, and our people make it possible.

10036.description: The NY Senior Medicare Patrol (SMP) works to empower seniors so that they can protect themselves against healthcare fraud, learn to detect errors on their medical statements and report Medicare abuse when suspected. With so many scams targeting seniors, volunteers have the unique opportunity to help stop healthcare fraud at the source! The NY Senior Medicare Patrol hosts sessions to teach seniors a variety of tips to ensure their healthcare benefits are safe & personal information is secure from scammers. What would a volunteer do? Senior Medicare Patrol volunteers will give education sessions to various audiences of Medicare beneficiaries, & caregivers about Medicare & Medicaid fraud/abuse. Sessions are hosted all throughout the 5 boroughs of NYC. No prior healthcare education? No problem! New York Senior Medicare Patrol will provide comprehensive training to interested volunteers. 2018 Upcoming Training: Thursday, March 15 at 10 AM - 1 PM Register NOW! Contact Victoria Thornton, Volunteer Coordinator for more information! 212-398-6565 ext 235 , vthornton@liveon-ny.org
10036.title: Teach Seniors in NYC!

10036.description: Come join us as we educate children about healthy eating, food and taste. What do Volunteers do? Volunteers are an essential component of the work that we do with children, helping out in the classroom but also providing a mentoring role for children. After participating in a hands on training, volunteers are partnered with a Spoons Across America Educator and assist in all aspects of program implementation. We look for an ongoing commitment between volunteers and a particular classroom or school, yet can also accommodate one-time volunteers. Volunteer responsibilities include assisting with program set up, working directly with children, teaching cooking skills, and assisting in the kitchen where appropriate. We are looking for individuals enthusiastic about healthy eating and children’s programming to join us! When and where are your programs? We teach programs for school children across the NYC boroughs. Programs occur throughout the school year and there are opportunities for an extended commitment as well as one-time opportunities. Will I be trained? All volunteers receive training at the Spoons Across America offices (630 Ninth Ave @ 44 th St in Manhattan), and are required to attend one of the following training dates: Monday, November 6: 6:00-7:30 Monday, November 13th 11:30-1:00 What programs do you have? We have a number of on-going programs for school age children in New York City. See our website www.spoonsacrossamerica.org for details. I'm ready to go! How do I sign up? If you are interested in volunteering with Spoons Across America this year. Please contact Ali McDowell, Director of Programs and Partnerships, at ali@spoonsacrossamerica.org. In your email, please indicate the following: - Training session you will attend: Monday 11/6 (evening) or Monday 11/13 (day) * Please note: Volunteers must complete a background check prior to the program date I want to volunteer, but I am not available right now. Will there be other opportunities to get involved? Definitely! If you are unable to volunteer at this point, we will have other opportunities available this winter and spring. If possible, please attend one of the trainings in October. Programs are ongoing and once you are trained you will be able to volunteer. Additional trainings will be held later this year. I want to volunteer, but I can’t attend the training.Will there be other trainings? Depending upon need and availability, additional trainings may be scheduled this fall. Please contact Ali with your availability. * Do you work for a business or company that wants to make a volunteer commitment? We can schedule a special training sessions for groups of 10 or more people, onsite or at our offices. Contact Ali for more information.
10036.title: Help Create Healthy Food Explorers: Volunteer with our Food Educators in NYC Elementary Classrooms
10036.org: From Farm to Table d/b/a Spoons Across America
